quotes.topic_title: Co-creating products with early power users
quotes.text: The way we think about product development at Stripe, it really is to find the correct set of early users to kind of co-create the product with.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A clear methodology: deliberately select early users and treat them as co-builders rather than passive feedback sources.

quotes.topic_title: Co-creating products with early power users
quotes.text: Maybe the best example of that is Stripe billing.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Anchors the co-creation approach in a concrete product example practitioners can model.

quotes.topic_title: Co-creating products with early power users
quotes.text: So we had shared Slack channels, we'd actually show them product on a very regular basis, get their feedback on it.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Describes a practical feedback-loop mechanism teams can replicate to tighten iteration cycles with power users.

quotes.topic_title: Co-creating products with early power users
quotes.text: And only when that original kind of Alpha group was super, super happy with the product did we then think it might be ready to go to a broader audience.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A launch readiness criterion that prioritizes deep satisfaction from a small alpha cohort before scaling distribution.

quotes.topic_title: Co-creating products with early power users
quotes.text: And that means that every engineer building product at Stripe really has many of the kind of attributes and will exercise many of the attributes that'll you often find in PMs in other companies.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A counterintuitive org design insight: engineers are expected to operate with PM-like behaviors in the product-building process.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We dig into Stripe's unique approach to hiring, how they built a very product oriented engineering team, which allowed them to hold off on hiring their first product manager for many, many years,
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive org design choice—product-oriented engineering strong enough to delay hiring PMs for years.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: how they operationalize their operating principle of be meticulous in your craft, including a number of fascinating internal processes like engineer occasions, walking the store and something called friction logging.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to a concrete methodology for turning a cultural value (“be meticulous”) into repeatable processes teams can adopt.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: David also shares what it takes to run an engineering culture with the uptime and scale requirements of Stripe, plus how AI is already impacting how they work and lessons around leadership management and planning.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals practical guidance on reliability culture at scale and early operational impacts of AI on engineering work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And when it comes to using data, a lot of teams think that they only have two choices. Make quick decisions based on gut feelings or make data driven decisions at a snail's pace. But that's a false choice.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that challenges the common speed-vs-rigor tradeoff in product decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But that's a false choice. You shouldn't have to compromise on speed to get product answers that you can trust.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Mixpanel)
quotes.context: Challenges the common speed-vs-rigor tradeoff in product decision-making and argues teams can have both.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Get deep insights at the speed of thought at a fair price that scales as you grow.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Mixpanel)
quotes.context: A practical standard for evaluating analytics tooling: fast insights plus scalable cost structure.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic, click through metrics and instead use your North Star metrics like activation, retention, subscription and payments.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Actionable measurement guidance for experimentation: optimize on North Star metrics rather than shallow engagement proxies.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo supports tests on front end, on the backend, email marketing, even machine learning claims.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Concrete example of broad experimentation surface area practitioners can aim to enable across their stack.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe Sessions and learning from customers
quotes.text: Stripe Sessions is our annual user conference, so we get together a bunch of folks from businesses building on Stripe and it's a great opportunity both to share what we've been up to over the last year, but also just learned a lot from them about what they would like to see us doing.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Highlights a practical customer-learning loop: use a user conference not just for announcements, but to directly gather input on what customers want next.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe Sessions and learning from customers
quotes.text: And so I find it very energizing.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Suggests that direct customer engagement can be a source of energy and motivation, not just a drain, reframing how leaders might view big customer events.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe Sessions and learning from customers
quotes.text: It is of course a lot of work to put it together. In particular, I'm spending a bunch of time getting some demos together today, which I love building demos so, but it's a real pleasure to join you today.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Emphasizes the operational reality and leverage of demos as a concrete way to communicate product value during major customer moments.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe attracts and retains top talent
quotes.text: When we find that confluence of kind of need and then adjacency to what we're already doing, that's usually our invitation to go and build the next layer of our economic infrastructure.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A practical product expansion heuristic: follow user needs that are adjacent to your current strengths to decide what to build next.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe attracts and retains top talent
quotes.text: First of all, a lot of people, most people I think come to Stripe because they see that there is this great opportunity to help businesses at scale.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A recruiting insight: top talent is drawn to high-leverage missions where their work helps many customers at once.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe attracts and retains top talent
quotes.text: We don't have to be out having the splashy launch, but hopefully all of our users can and we are quietly working behind the scenes to make their businesses better and more effective over time.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A counterintuitive positioning lesson: infrastructure companies can win by optimizing for customer outcomes over public visibility.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe attracts and retains top talent
quotes.text: So especially for critical roles, leadership hiring in particular, we're happy to take our time and meet tens or hundreds of people.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A concrete hiring practice: treat key roles as a long search process with very high sampling, not a fast funnel.

quotes.topic_title: How Stripe attracts and retains top talent
quotes.text: Very, very many people at Stripe today are doing a quite different job to the one that they join for.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A retention/learning model: design roles and culture so people can grow into new jobs internally rather than needing to leave to evolve.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe’s structured, realistic interview loops
quotes.text: One of the things is we do have structured hiring loops. So we put everyone through a very consistent process, so very personal as we help folks figure out why they might want to be here. But then we have a consistent way of evaluating talent.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A practical methodology: combine a consistent evaluation loop with a candidate-friendly, personalized experience.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe’s structured, realistic interview loops
quotes.text: The other thing that these loops have in common is nothing is a trick question. We try to put people into an environment which is as close to doing the actual work together as we possibly can.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A clear hiring principle: avoid puzzles and instead simulate real work to predict on-the-job performance.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe’s structured, realistic interview loops
quotes.text: It's actually kind of pair programming welcome to use Google to search for Stack Overflow to search for answers. We don't care. We just want to see the outcome.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Counter to many interview norms: allowing real-world tools shifts assessment from memorization to execution and results.

quotes.topic_title: Stripe’s structured, realistic interview loops
quotes.text: The written exercises tend to be something that you do in your own time. We suggest a time bind so it's not an unreasonable demand in the rest of your life.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A candidate-respectful tactic: time-box take-home work to reduce burden while still getting signal.

quotes.topic_title: Product-minded engineers and PM role at Stripe
quotes.text: The best PMs for developer focused products I think are usually very technical. They're mostly former engineers themselves or maybe kind of current engineers still tinkering on the side, but bringing a lot of user insight and strategy to the problem.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A hiring/role design heuristic for developer-product PMs: optimize for technical depth plus user insight and strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Product-minded engineers and PM role at Stripe
quotes.text: So I mean, in fact, the way we think about product development at Stripe, it really is to find the correct set of early users to kind of co-create the product with.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A clear product-development methodology: deliberately select early users and co-create with them rather than building in isolation.

quotes.topic_title: Product-minded engineers and PM role at Stripe
quotes.text: So we had shared Slack channels, we'd actually show them product on a very regular basis, get their feedback on it. And only when that original kind of Alpha group was super, super happy with the product did we then think it might be ready to go to a broader audience.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable loop for early product validation: tight feedback cadence with an alpha cohort before broader launch.

quotes.topic_title: Product-minded engineers and PM role at Stripe
quotes.text: And PMs play just this absolute linchpin role across a lot of that.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A memorable framing of PM impact at scale: PMs as the cross-functional connector in complex, multi-stakeholder product work.

quotes.topic_title: Product-minded engineers and PM role at Stripe
quotes.text: They often and usually also bring a lot of the product strategy, okay, this is what we're doing today, but what does it ladder up to and therefore how do we make the right choices to make sure that we're taking the right longer term path.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A practical definition of PM strategy work: connect today’s decisions to a longer-term ladder-up to guide tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing 'be meticulous in your craft'
quotes.text: So at Stripe we have operating principles and they're kind of like corporate values, but they're not just values, they're much less abstract than that.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A practical framing for turning vague values into concrete, behavior-guiding principles teams can actually use.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing 'be meticulous in your craft'
quotes.text: So actually, we were just talking about the early Stripe team. I think one of the best things that they did, I mean they did a bunch of great stuff, finding early product market fit, but one of the most foresighted things that they did was to kind of take a little detour and think about what is it about how we've been working so far that we think has made us successful and is going to be important as we continue to scale.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A repeatable method: pause to codify the behaviors that made you successful before scaling amplifies inconsistency.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing 'be meticulous in your craft'
quotes.text: And something that really delighted me was that when I started integrating the product, there were parts of the experience where I was stuck. So I made a mistake with how it integrated API. I was getting an error message back, but I wasn't stuck for very long because something that the team at Stripe had done was we made the error messages coming out of our API link to the piece of the docs that told you how to solve the problem.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A concrete craft tactic: turn high-friction moments (errors) into guided recovery by linking directly to the relevant docs.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing 'be meticulous in your craft'
quotes.text: So we have a process that is widely used across product teams that even like folks building stuff internally for Stripes to use, which we call friction logging.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Names a specific, portable methodology teams can adopt to systematically find where meticulousness will pay off most.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing 'be meticulous in your craft'
quotes.text: And by the way, the example I gave you on the error message is there's actually more code in the jobs that serve the Stripe API to handle those edge cases than in the actual main flow.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A counterintuitive investment principle: edge cases can deserve more engineering than the happy path because they dominate user pain and trust.

quotes.topic_title: Friction logging: cadence, template, and prioritization
quotes.text: For years and years, I have gone through the process of onboarding [inaudible 00:33:28] user to Stripe once a month, writing a friction log and then tagging in the right people across the company that might need to take action on some of the things that we're observing.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A concrete cadence + workflow example (monthly end-to-end run + friction log + routing to owners) that teams can copy.

quotes.topic_title: Friction logging: cadence, template, and prioritization
quotes.text: And one of the reasons that that kind of process of taking a big step back is useful is at this stage we have many people, we have thousands of engineers who are working in parallel.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Explains the scaling rationale: friction logging as a coordination mechanism when many teams ship in parallel.

quotes.topic_title: Friction logging: cadence, template, and prioritization
quotes.text: it literally is say what you want to do, be very explicit about the user that you are trying to have a mental model for because that helps you make the right choices as you go through the flow. And then really just keep a very clear stream of consciousness log of what you're finding as you build.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable template: define the goal, specify persona, then capture stream-of-consciousness friction notes.

quotes.topic_title: Friction logging: cadence, template, and prioritization
quotes.text: By the way, also really important, praise the stuff that's good.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Counterbalances “bug lists” with recognition, making friction logs motivating and culturally reinforcing.

quotes.topic_title: Friction logging: cadence, template, and prioritization
quotes.text: It varies by team and varies by stage of product. So there is no Stripe kind of like we will reserve 50% of our time to do this stuff. That wouldn't make any sense. But we do encourage and ask every team to think hard about how much should they be setting aside for those kind of activities.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Rejects a one-size-fits-all allocation rule and instead pushes teams to explicitly plan capacity for polish and remediations.

quotes.topic_title: UX reviews, 'walk the store,' and shared quality bar
quotes.text: We also find it very valuable to go through that process together.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Emphasizes that UX review quality improves when teams experience and evaluate flows collaboratively, not just asynchronously.

quotes.topic_title: UX reviews, 'walk the store,' and shared quality bar
quotes.text: And then just discussing very openly actually the way that we do this today is we have a log of issues that we want to talk about that anyone can type into while the PM usually is walking us through the flow.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable method for running UX reviews: live issue logging during a guided walkthrough.

quotes.topic_title: UX reviews, 'walk the store,' and shared quality bar
quotes.text: So someone once described this to me as if you were a chef, you're going to taste the soup and you're going to talk to your kitchen staff about what went into the soup when it was good and wasn't so good.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A memorable analogy that frames product reviews as a craft practice—taste together, then diagnose inputs and process.

quotes.topic_title: UX reviews, 'walk the store,' and shared quality bar
quotes.text: So we have a weekly meeting called Friday Fireside where you don't have to attend, but the majority of the company does attend and we've done a few series where we'll actually go through some really, really interesting critical product flows together and talk about how this is reflecting various priorities that we have and shifts that we're trying to make, but in particular with the user experience and a particular user at the core.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A specific example of scaling UX quality via company-wide “Walk the Store” sessions anchored on real flows and a user lens.

quotes.topic_title: UX reviews, 'walk the store,' and shared quality bar
quotes.text: I think almost anything that you talk about is a value. I mean, being a value matters, but you need to have a practice behind that. That means that the value becomes real for everyone.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Challenges “values-only” culture-building by insisting on operational practices that make values tangible and repeatable.

quotes.topic_title: Preparing teams for exec product reviews
quotes.text: At Stripe, and I think it's probably goes for most companies, but at Stripe, the main answer here is put your user's hat on and if you understand your user well and what they're seeking to get out of the experience and anchor any questions you get asked or wobbles you may feel of like, oh, that was an out of the blue question back to well here's, remember what we're trying to do for our users, that usually makes any meeting like that go really well.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A practical mental model for staying grounded in exec reviews: continually re-anchor discussion and surprises to user goals and intended experience.

quotes.topic_title: Preparing teams for exec product reviews
quotes.text: So I mean a risk that exists in any company as you get to run a bigger team or whatever is that individual contributors, individuals will have a very small amount of time with you in general.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Highlights a scaling dynamic that changes how feedback lands: limited exec access increases the weight of each interaction.

quotes.topic_title: Preparing teams for exec product reviews
quotes.text: So there's always a risk that you might make a kind of fairly unimportant remark and it will be taken out of context to be something very important.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A cautionary observation for leaders: casual comments can be over-interpreted, so precision and framing matter.

quotes.topic_title: Preparing teams for exec product reviews
quotes.text: So I personally also try very hard to anchor feedback I'm giving in what's the user experience we're trying to deliver? Does this actually matter? Recognizing that that is a risk and yeah, it definitely takes constant practice.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: An actionable feedback method: tie critique to user experience and importance to prevent misinterpretation and reduce stress.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for building better products: tight user loops
quotes.text: If you have a mechanism to listen to users, get something in their hands quite quickly and then get their feedback on it to run it back through a feedback loop, you're very unlikely to go wrong.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A practical methodology for building better products: ship quickly to users, learn, and iterate via a tight feedback loop.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for building better products: tight user loops
quotes.text: Especially if you put a lot of thought into these being the right users whose needs you want to focus on because they ladder up to your strategy.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: Highlights that feedback loops only work if you deliberately choose users aligned with your strategy, not just any users.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for building better products: tight user loops
quotes.text: So if you don't have that feedback loop, and actually it's remarkable as I talk to folks across the industry and so forth, it's remarkable how frequently that feedback loop doesn't exist in product development cycles.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that many teams still lack the most basic product-development mechanism: a real user feedback loop.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for building better products: tight user loops
quotes.text: And at Stripe, we focus a lot on all of our developer tooling and infrastructure on making it possible for changes to get delivered continuously to production so we can get them in front of users very rapidly and that's really important.
quotes.speaker: David Singleton
quotes.context: A concrete example of investing in continuous delivery infrastructure to shorten the idea-to-user-feedback cycle.
